document.docAuthor: Ishikawa, Tadashi, Cai, Wanzhi & Tomokuni, Masaaki
document.docTitle: Abelocephala major Ishikawa, Cai & Tomokuni, 2015, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: The assassin bug subfamily Tribelocephalinae (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Reduviidae) from Japan, with descriptions of eight new species in the genera Opistoplatys and Abelocephala

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: The assassin bug subfamily Tribelocephalinae (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Reduviidae) from Japan, with descriptions of eight new species in the genera Opistoplatys and Abelocephala

subSubSection.paragraph: Diagnosis. This species is recognized by the following combination of character states: body approximately 5.5 mm long; mandibular plate nearly right-angled at anterior corner and weakly projected anteriorly in dorsal view; rostral segment I more than twice as long as segment II; posterior pronotal lobe yellowish brown; outer (larger) cell of hemelytral membrane rounded apically; and posterior process of pygophore wide with weakly curved apical margin in dorsal view.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 93–104. Left antenna of
Abelocephala nakatai
(93–98) and
A . yaeyamensis
(99–104), dorsal view, setae omitted. 93–95, 99–101, male; 96–98, 102–104, female. 93, 96, 99, 102, segment I; 94, 97, 100, 103, segment II; 95, 98, 101, 104, flagellum. Scale bars: 0.2 mm.

FIGURES 105–113. Left antenna of
Abelocephala major
(105–110) and
A . longiceps
(111–113), dorsal view, setae omitted. 105–107, 111–113, male; 108–110, female. 105, 108, 111, segment I; 106, 109, 112, segment II; 107, 110, 113, flagellum. Scale bar: 0.2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Pronotum (
Fig. 49
) approximately 0.7 times as long as humeral width; anterior lobe 0.6 times as long as posterior lobe along midline, 0.7 times as wide as humeral width. Hemelytron (
Figs. 49
, 118 ) wide, twice as long as its maximum width, exceeding apex of abdomen by approximately 0.2 times of its length; outer (larger) cell of membrane (
Fig. 118
) rounded apically.

A . yaeyamensis

subSubSection.paragraph: Measurements [in mm, ♂ (n= 2 ) /♀ (n= 1 ), holotype in parentheses]. Body length 5.33–5.77 / 5.17 ( 5.77 ). Head length 1.14–1.16 / 1.12 ( 1.14 ), width across eyes 0.82–0.83 / 0.78 ( 0.82 ). Lengths of antennal segments I and II 1.00– 1.14 / 0.98 (1.00) and 1.00– 1.17 / 1.02 (1.00), respectively. Lengths of rostral segments I and II 0.98 –1.00/ 0.91 (1.00) and 0.43–0.44 / 0.43 ( 0.44 ), respectively. Pronotum length 1.13–1.18 / 1.12 ( 1.13 ), width across humeri 1.66–1.68 / 1.55 ( 1.68 ). Hemelytron length 4.35–4.43 / 4.38 ( 4.35 ). Lengths of femur and tibia of fore leg 1.42–1.48 / 1.33 ( 1.42 ) and 1.46–1.52 / 1.37 ( 1.46 ); of mid leg 1.43–1.47 / 1.30 ( 1.43 ) and 1.46–1.49 / 1.35 ( 1.46 ); of hind leg 1.90–2.01 / 1.84 ( 1.90 ) and 1.96–2.04 / 1.84 ( 1.96 ). Abdomen length 2.74–3.18 / 2.84 ( 3.18 ), maximum width 2.50–2.57 / 2.54 ( 2.57 ).

Holotype
. ♂ (
Fig. 49
), “[Yona Forest] Okinawa-jima Is. The Loochoos June 4, 1966 S. Tachikawa leg.” ( LETUA IC 2014 -00220) ( TUA ).

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. Japan : Ryukyu Islands (Amami-Oshima Is., Okinawa Is.).

Etymology. From the Latin
major
, referring to the relatively large body among the congeners of the genus Abelocephala ; an adjective.

Remarks. Only the macropterous form of this species is known. In general habitus, this new species is resembles
A . yaeyamensis
sp. nov.
However,
A . major
sp. nov.
can be distinguished from
A . yaeyamensis
sp. nov.
by the mandibular plate nearly right-angled at the anterior corner and weakly projected anteriorly in dorsal view (
Fig. 62
) [vs. acutely angled at the anterior corner and strongly projected anteriorly in dorsal view (
Fig. 60
)], the outer (larger) cell of the hemelytral membrane rounded apically (
Fig. 118
) [vs. acutely angled apically (
Fig. 117
)], the posterior process of the pygophore wide in dorsal view (Fig. 130 ) [vs. narrow in dorsal view (Fig. 129 )], and valvula I with approximately eight setae (
Fig. 153
) [vs. with approximately four setae (
Fig. 152
)].

We collected only a few specimens of
A . major
sp. nov.
However, our observations suggest that the habitat preference of this new species is similar to those of the other Japanese members of Abelocephala . No additional information regarding the biology of this reduviid is available.
